Borobudur remains popular for pilgrimage.

Borobudur Temple is nothing short of a masterpiece, a testament to the grandeur and ingenuity of ancient civilizations. As one of the largest and most impressive Buddhist monuments in the world, it offers an awe-inspiring experience that is sure to leave a lasting impression on anyone fortunate enough to visit.  From the moment you approach Borobudur, the sheer scale and intricacy of the structure take your breath away. Each level of the temple reveals a new layer of stunning detail – from the intricately carved stone reliefs that tell stories of ancient wisdom to the towering stupas that stand as silent sentinels against the backdrop of lush green hills. The craftsmanship and artistry that went into creating this monument are truly remarkable.  As you ascend the terraces, you not only feel a sense of physical elevation but also a spiritual one. The journey to the top is symbolic, representing a path to enlightenment, and the panoramic views that greet you at the summit are nothing short of spectacular. Standing at the peak, surrounded by mist-covered mountains and the lush landscape of Central Java, you can’t help but feel a profound connection to the past and a deep appreciation for the cultural heritage that Borobudur represents.  Visiting Borobudur is more than just a sightseeing trip; it’s an immersive experience that takes you on a journey through time, culture, and spirituality. Whether you’re a history buff, a cultural enthusiast, or simply someone who appreciates the beauty of human achievement, Borobudur Temple is a must-visit destination that will leave you in awe of its grandeur.  In summary, Borobudur Temple is a majestic and unforgettable destination. Its stunning architecture, rich history, and spiritual significance make it one of the most extraordinary places on Earth. A visit here is not just recommended – it’s essential for anyone exploring Indonesia.

For about three centuries, Matalan, located in the heart of the Progo Valley on the southern slopes of Mount Merapi, became the center of Javanese Hindu and Buddhist culture. This period witnessed many religious buildings, including the World Heritage Sites of Borobudur and Prambanan.  Borobudur is a Mahayana Buddhist temple built in the 8th and 9th centuries for more than a thousand years. It was buried in volcanic ash for hundreds of years and covered with jungles on the surface until it was discovered by the British in 1814 and reappeared in the world. Borobudur is the largest Buddhist building in the world today. It has 9 floors above ground and 6 floors below for the realm of desire and sex. It is rich in various reliefs. It depicts stories from Buddhist books and is 3 kilometers long. It tells the stories of ordinary beings from Palace life to the common people in the village. The upper three floors are the formless realm, which is the world of gods who are freed from reincarnation and no longer attached to the secular world. Therefore, there are no secular sculptures. There are 72 small bell-shaped pagodas surrounding the large pagoda in the middle.  Tickets cost NT$240 for locals and NT$900 for foreigners, which is not cheap based on local prices. However, since the restoration of historical sites requires a lot of manpower and money, it is better to pay if you have the money.

Lake Toba is one of the most iconic and fascinating places in Sumatra, as well as the largest volcanic lake in the world. Lake Toba offers a number of recreational activities for visitors. You can take a cruise on the lake, enjoy the panoramic view of the surrounding mountains, and visit the islands in the center of the lake, such as Samosir Island, which is famous for its Batak culture and local traditions. The lake's waters are calm and refreshing, offering the opportunity for swimming, kayaking or fishing. It is also possible to hike the surrounding mountains to enjoy spectacular views of the lake and the surrounding environment. The area around Lake Toba also offers rich culture and history. You can visit traditional Batak villages to learn about local culture, visit museums that tell the history of the area, and try traditional Batak cuisine. In summary, Lake Toba is a natural wonder that offers a combination of scenic beauty, recreational activities and local culture. It is an ideal place to relax, explore and immerse yourself in the beauty of Sumatra

Mirror Rock Cave (Indonesian: Goa Batu Cermin) can be said to be another famous attraction in Labuan Bajo besides waterfalls. However, the so-called Mirror Rock Cave is actually just a cave. The thick-browed boy has seen a lot of it before. There is a large bamboo forest along the road from the entrance of the scenic spot to the entrance of the cave. It is elegant and very cool, making it more comfortable as you walk. After walking for about 10 minutes, we reached the entrance of Jingshi Cave. Unexpectedly, the rocks in the cave have strange shapes and come in many different colors, which dazzled the thick-browed boy. The rock wall near the entrance of the cave is occupied by tree roots, giving it an atmosphere of searching for secrets. The tour guide told us that this area was the seabed in ancient times. The evidence is that there are many fossils of corals and other marine life on the rocks. It's pitch dark inside the cave, so bring a flashlight. There is a prehistoric turtle fossil in the cave, which is so completely preserved that even the head is clearly identifiable. From time to time, shell fossils are found on the rock wall, just like a fossil museum. There is a fossil of a prehistoric fish near the entrance of the cave, and the fins are still clearly visible. Although the place is not big, the rock shapes here are extremely beautiful, and you can see fossils, so it is definitely worth a visit.

If it is not possible due to health reasons to walk a few meters while crouching down, you can save yourself the visit. In the cave itself you are shown some particularly beautiful shapes, bats (which sometimes fly close), fossil finds and of course the room from which the cave gets its name. No matter what travel guides write, there is no ONE TIME where everything reflects. You don't have to be an astronomer to understand that the position of the sun varies daily. The tour itself lasts a maximum of an hour. Here too I was impressed by the friendliness. Afterwards there was a coffee and I made my way to Rangko Cave.
